<div><strong><br></strong></div><p><span style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122); background-color: rgb(255, 242, 202);"><strong><inline style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122); background-color: rgb(195, 214, 155);">KK 2.1 FLIGHT CONTROLLER BOARD :</inline></strong></span></p><p style="margin-left: 20px;">KK 2.1 is flight controller boardis a flight control board for multi-rotor aircraft (Tricopters, Quadcopters, Hexcopters etc). Its purpose is to stabilize the aircraft during flight. To do this it takes the signal from the 6050MPU gyro/acc (roll, pitch and yaw) then passes the signal to the Atmega644PA IC. The Atmega644PA IC unit then processes these signals according the users selected firmware and passes control signals to the installed Electronic Speed Controllers (ESCs). These signals instruct the ESCs to make fine adjustments to the motors rotational speed which in turn stabilizes multi-rotor .                                                                                                                 aft.<img data-sz="f" name="X90qSvtt28VUPM:" class="rg_i" alt="Image result for kk 2.1" jsaction="load:str.tbn" src="data:image/jpeg;base64," style="width: 258px; height: 189px; margin-left: -19px; margin-right: -18px; margin-top: 0px;"></p><p style="margin-left: 20px;">This flight control board also uses signals from your radio systems receiver (Rx) and passes these signals to the Atmega644PA IC via the aileron, elevator, throttle and rudder inputs. Once this information has been processed the IC will send varying signals to the ESCs which in turn adjust the rotational speed of each motor to induce controlled flight (up, down, backwards, forwards, left, right, yaw). </p><p><span style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122); background-color: rgb(255, 242, 202);"><strong><inline style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122); background-color: rgb(195, 214, 155);">QUAD-COPTER BODY :</inline></strong></span></p><p style="margin-left: 20px;"><strong style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122);"><span style="background-color: rgb(195, 214, 155);">ARMS :</span></strong></p><p style="margin-left: 40px;"><strong style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122);"><span style="background-color: rgb(195, 214, 155);"></span></strong>As name suggest there are 4 arms in body. More the holes in arm, lesser will be the vibrations. That's why it is always prefered to use the arms with maximum holes.</p><p style="margin-left: 20px;"><strong style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122);"><span style="background-color: rgb(195, 214, 155);">MOTORS :</span></strong></p><p style="margin-left: 40px;"><strong style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122);"><span style="background-color: rgb(195, 214, 155);"></span></strong>For multi rotors generally used motors are brushless beacause of its high rpm. There are various types of motors can be used on the arm length, throttle required .Choosing the appropriate motor depends on mainly two factors the kv value and the max. current . The detail is explained in Details section.</p><p style="margin-left: 20px;"><strong style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122);"><span style="background-color: rgb(195, 214, 155);">Electronic Speed Controller (ESC) :</span></strong></p><p style="margin-left: 40px;">Controls the rpm of motor according to sent by Flight Controller board.</p><p style="margin-left: 20px;"><strong style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122);"><span style="background-color: rgb(195, 214, 155);">POWER DISTRIBUTION BOARD :</span></strong></p><p style="margin-left: 40px;"><strong style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122);"><span style="background-color: rgb(195, 214, 155);"></span></strong>Distributes power from battery to ESCs.</p><p style="margin-left: 20px;"><strong style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122);"><span style="background-color: rgb(195, 214, 155);">PROPELLERS :</span></strong></p><p style="margin-left: 40px;">Four propellers are required with a pair of different orientation (clockwise and anti-clockwise). Length depends on Quad-copter frame.</p><p style="margin-left: 40px;"></p><p><strong></strong><span style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122); background-color: rgb(255, 242, 202);"><strong><inline style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122); background-color: rgb(195, 214, 155);">Altitude Hold :</inline></strong></span></p><p style="margin-left: 20px;"><span style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122); background-color: rgb(255, 242, 202);"><strong><inline style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122); background-color: rgb(195, 214, 155);"></inline></strong></span>SONAR:</p><p style="margin-left: 40px;">SONAR (SOund Navigation And Ranging) ises ultra frequency sound waves to measure the height from the ground or any obstacle.</p><p style="margin-left: 40px;">It contains one transmitter and a receiver, and depending upon time interval and speed of sound it measures the distance.</p><p><img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/gz4i3.jpg"></p><p style="margin-left: 20px;">We attached a SONAR sensor at the bottom of the Quad., It continuously sends the elevation (height from the ground) to the Arduino, in real time.</p><p style="margin-left: 20px;">If quad is in Autonomous mode, then Arduino compare the height value sent by the sensor to the predefined value if value from sensor is less than or more than the stored value, Arduino sends signal to KK board to change throtlle value accordingly so that it can get the height.</p><p style="margin-left: 20px;">This way with the help of SONAR altitude hold can be achieved.</p><p><span style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122); background-color: rgb(195, 214, 155);"><strong>SELF STABILIZATION : </strong></span></p><p><strong><span style="color: rgb(95, 73, 122); background-color: rgb(195, 214, 155);">GPS : </span></strong></p><p style="margin-left: 20px;">GPS module (receiver) connected to quad receives the current coordinates of the quad and sends to to the Arduino. GPS module we have is 66 channel and has frequency 1 Hz (which can be increased to 10 Hz, but it reduces the accuracy). More number of channel ensures the lesser starting time. 1 Hz means it updates the position every second.</p><p style="margin-left: 20px;">Arduino then joins the current coordinates to the destination coordinates and it sends KK board according signals so that quad orients itself in the direction of line joining coordinates and proceeds. This repeats every time GPS updates position, i.e. 1Hz. Doing it repeatedly path follower can be achieved.</p>
